title: NIK SIMON'S GAIN LINE: England, Naomi Osaka and Eddie Jones all feature
text:
Will England pay for Sherylle’s departure?

Eyebrows were raised when popular ‘eye coach’ Dr Sherylle Calder was seen flying home early from Tokyo on Monday.

England players have worked closely with the South African to improve hand-eye coordination and reaction skills but Calder and her colleague Christi Botha are only contracted to work a set number of days per season.

In an ideal world, Eddie Jones would surely have kept them out for longer. But a cash crisis has hit the head coach’s World Cup plans, with former captain Will Carling even forced to go on a fundraising mission in the City of London to cover a six-figure shortfall. If the RFU were not cutting back, perhaps Calder’s presence for the knockout stages would have been a wise investment.

Dr Sherylle Calder was seen flying home early from the World Cup and Tokyo on Monday

Eddie Jones refused to conduct pre-match radio interviews with the BBC on Saturday for the first time. The England coach has spoken to the brilliant 5 Live commentary team before every match of his four-year tenure, but this week he snubbed them after taking issue with a headline on their website.

Jones was unhappy with the way his comments about Scotland’s legal battle with World Rugby over Typhoon Hagibis were presented.

Naomi: Yes, I’m a Blossom fan now!

Japan’s players received a good luck message from local tennis star Naomi Osaka ahead of today’s quarter-final against South Africa.

The two-time Grand Slam winner said she was converted to the sport after giving wing Yu Tamura his man of the match award after Japan’s win over Scotland. Osaka, 22, said: ‘My message to the team is that you have made the country so proud. All the best and enjoy the moment. You can do it.

‘I am definitely a rugby fan for life now. And, yes, I have a shirt signed by all the team.’

Osaka’s schedule prevented her from attending the game.

Naomi Osaka says she is a Blossoms fan after the country's fine World Cup run

Michael Leitch mania continues in Japan with fans queuing for up to two hours for coffee at the captain’s coffee shop in western Tokyo.

The branch is called ‘Plus Sixty Four’ which is the international dialling code for New Zealand, where Leitch was born.

Michael Leitch hysteria continues as fans go to the Japan captain's coffee shop in Tokyo

Wales were helped to prepare for their quarter-final with France by a more-than-qualified drinks carrier — chief executive Martyn Phillips.

WRU boss Phillips, who earns in excess of £300,000-a-year, is back in Japan for the latter stages. He was in the Far East at the start of the tournament to deal with the departure of coach Rob Howley over alleged betting breaches.

At their captain’s run in Beppu on Sunday, it was all hands on deck with Phillips stepping in to help Warren Gatland’s players stay hydrated. Phillips, wearing a Wales team tracksuit, took orders from assistant strength and conditioning coach John Ashby.

QBE Business Insurance has developed a set of predictions for the World Cup based on a mathematical formula created by their team of experts. The QBE Rugby Predictor simulated the entire tournament 3,750 times.

Every match was replicated by generating the number of tries, conversions and kicks scored by each team. QBE’s predictions for today’s are Wales 24 France 13 France and Japan 25 South Africa 31.
description: England players have worked closely with the doctor to improve hand-eye coordination skills but Caldon is only contracted to work a set number of days per season and she left on Monday.
authors: Nik Simon For The Mail On Sunday
